section.p: The following prerequisites must be fulfilled before you can create and publish services in :

ul.li: To create technical services for the AWSROROpenStackTPS5vSphereAzure integration in , you must have access to as a technology manager. You must be a member of the technology provider organization responsible for the AWSROROpenStackTPS5VMwareAzure service controller as specified in the configuration settings for the installation.

In ROR, appropriate templates for virtual platforms (L-Platforms) and images for virtual servers (Virtual Image Pool) must exist, to which the technical services in can be mapped. The ROR user specified in the configuration settings for the installation must have the necessary credentials to create and configure virtual platforms and servers based on these templates and images.
The ROR integration package includes technical services as samples. In order to use these samples, the virtual platforms in ROR must allow for configuring clusters consisting of up to 6 servers (1 master, up to 5 slaves). The servers must be operable with up to 4 CPUs.

In AWS, appropriate AMIs for virtual servers must exist, to which the technical services in can be mapped. The AWS user specified in the configuration settings for the installation must have the necessary credentials to create and configure virtual servers based on these AMIs.

Templates for the virtual systems to be provisioned must exist. They form the basis for the technical services in . The user specified in the configuration settings for the installation must have the necessary credentials to create and configure virtual systems for your organization based on these templates in OpenStack.
In FUJITSU Cloud Service K5, the cpf_systemowner role is required.

In TPS5, appropriate system templates for virtual platforms and images for virtual servers must exist, to which the technical services in can be mapped. The TSP5 user specified in the configuration settings for the installation must have the necessary credentials to create and configure virtual platforms based on these templates and images.

In vSphere, appropriate templates for the provisioning of VMs must exist, to which the technical services in can be mapped. The vSphere user specified in the configuration settings for the installation must have the necessary permissions to create and configure VMs based on these templates.

In Azure, the following is required:
A subscription on the account of which the virtual machines and additional resources are to be created.
An application (service principal) which acts on behalf of . You need to:
Know the ID of the Azure Active Directory (tenant ID) hosting the application and the application ID (client ID).
Have a valid authentication key for the application.
Assign the application at least Contributor permissions to the subscription if new resource groups are to be created, or at least Contributor permissions for the resource groups to which new virtual machines are to be added.
For details on how to create and obtain these items, refer to the Microsoft documentation on creating applications and service principals.
Appropriate images for the virtual machines to be created. You can use standard images from Microsoft or other providers or your own images which you have made available in Azure.
Optionally, resource groups with an existing network configuration to which virtual machines are to be added.
Optionally, storage accounts to be used with the virtual machines to be created.

Templates in JSON format for the Azure Resource Manager must exist in the environment of the Azure integration software. A template defines the virtual machines as well as other resources to be deployed and the dependencies between them.
For each Resource Manager template, a corresponding parameter definition file in JSON format must exist. It is used to pass the parameter values specified at subscription time to the Resource Manager template. For details on parameter definition files, the supported parameters, and their mapping to technical service parameters, refer to .
The Azure integration package contains sample Resource Manager templates and parameter definition files. You can use these files as a basis and adapt them as required. Additional templates can be defined with Azure Resource Manager. For details, refer to the Microsoft documentation.
The templates and parameter definition files need to be available in a location that can be accessed from and the Azure integration software by HTTP or HTTPS at runtime, for example, the docroot/templates directory of the app-domain domain in your application server.

To create marketable services for the AWSROROpenStackTPS5vSphereAzure integration in , you must have access to as a service manager of an organization with the supplier role. This may be the same organization as the technology provider organization or a different one.
To publish your marketable services, you must have access to an appropriate marketplace in in your service manager role.
